page.title: 02NATURE RESERVE AT LAVERNOCK
page.content: The nature reserve at Lavernock is a 14 acre area of scrubland extending along the cliff top from Lavernock Point (from where Marconi sent his first radio message across water) to St.Mary's Well Bay. The reserve is designated a{Site of {Special Scientific Interest.}This is because of the great variety and comparative rarity of some of the plants which grow there. These wild plants attract 20 species of butterflies to the reserve. In Britain there are 60 species of breeding butterflies. Only 8 species are not declining in numbers. This is because in most areas the profusion of wild plants has gone as land is ploughed and hedges and woodland are cleared for the cultivation of crops.
